title: HTML Headings
subject: HTML
learning_objectives: Understand the semantic importance of headings
Learn when to use h1 vs h6
theory:
# HTML Headings

HTML headings are titles or subtitles that you want to display on a webpage.

## The Heading Hierarchy

HTML offers **six** levels of headings, defined with the `<h1>` to `<h6>` tags.

*   `<h1>` defines the **most important** heading.
*   `<h6>` defines the **least important** heading.

### Size and Importance
Browsers automatically add some white space (a margin) before and after a heading. They also render the text in different sizes (h1 being the largest).

## Importance of Headings (SEO)

Search engines use your headings to index the structure and content of your web pages.

*   Users skim your pages by its headings. It is important to use headings to show the document structure.
*   `<h1>` should be used for the **main heading** of the page (usually only one per page).
*   `<h2>` should be used for main sub-sections.
*   `<h3>` for sub-sections of `<h2>`, and so on.

## Do NOT Use Headings for Size

**Important:** Do not use headings just to make text **BIG** or **bold**. Use headings only for structure. If you want big text that isn't a title, use CSS (e.g., `font-size`).

examples.explanation: Illustrates the visual hierarchy of the 6 heading levels.

examples.code:
Banana

Bananas are fruits.

Types of Bananas

There are many types...

Cavendish

The most common type.
examples.explanation: Proper nesting of headings helps screen readers and SEO.

common_mistakes.correction: Don't jump from h1 to h4. Follow the order: h1 -> h2 -> h3.
Best practice is one h1 per page (usually the page title).

interview_questions.question: How many heading tags are there in HTML?
Why are headings important for SEO?
interview_questions.answer: Search engines use headings to understand the structure and topic of the content. Keywords in headings carry more weight. Properly structured headings also improve accessibility for screen readers.

interview_questions.question: Can I use <h1> for normal text if I want it big?
interview_questions.answer: No. Headings represent structure/semantics. For visual styling (size/boldness) without structural meaning, use CSS.

practice_problems.problem: Create a document structure for a book with: Book Title (h1), Chapter 1 (h2), Section 1.1 (h3).

real_world_use_cases.description: Blind users can navigate a page by jumping from heading to heading. If you misuse headings for styling, their navigation breaks.

exam_notes: Use distinct headings for structure, not style
One h1 per page is best practice
summary: HTML headings (h1-h6) define the structure and hierarchy of your content. They are crucial for both SEO and accessibility. Always use them to create a logical outline of your page, starting with h1 for the main title and descending to h2, h3, etc.
